page.title: 08BRAYTON BARFF
page.content: Brayton Barff is a small sandstone hill to the west of Selby and just to the south of Thorpe Willoughby. Barff is a local word for a small hill. This hill is of great interest in the area as it is one of the few landmarks in an otherwise flat landscape. The Barff is covered in mixed woodland and also contains the Y.W.A. storage reservoir for the Selby area. Part of the Barff is a nature reserve and a nature trail has been marked out with numbered stones. The trail starts at a small car park on Barff Lane. Along the trail can be seen large oaks and sycamores and in the spring the hills are covered in bluebells. There is also a coniferous plantation with Scots Pines and Norway Spruce. The woods are inhabited by grey squirrels,foxes and rabbits as well as a profusion of birds,notably the jay.
